dialogues.text: Since I had kids, my boobs are just gone. They didn't even say goodbye. They just left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the time I'm forty, these are going to go National Geographic on me.

dialogues.text: I feel bad about myself right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think this is a really good offer on the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We expected more. I mean, I know it's a bad market but that's still way under what we were looking for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, but based on the market, it's like you're gaining money. Because it's so much more than what you deserve. But these people are from Iran and they don't really know that they're offering too much. Is there any chance that Debbie will go for it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt it. I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a lot of inventory out there. What's her problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, really quick. Charlotte leaves with the triplets.

dialogues.text: Gluten's really bad for you.

dialogues.text: I don't think so. It's wheat.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Don't you watch Dr. Oz?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: As in the Wizard of?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Hey, Mom. We were wondering if we could use the computer to iChat.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Remember the rules? Eight to eight- thirty?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I have a friend over.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Hi Wendy. Why don't you guys go play? You could go build a fort!

dialogues.text: Remember the Alamo?

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Have you ever built a fort, Wendy?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Like on Facebook?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I will take this if you're going to throw it away, because at our house, we're wheat eaters.

dialogues.text: But don't you want to live long enough to see your kids grow up?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: That's up to god, honey.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: But that's really not good for the kids.

dialogues.text: The kids eat grass. This is fine. Larry takes some of the food she's throwing out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy's mom lets her go on whenever she wants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mom's pretty cool about it as long as I finish my homework.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Well, I guess I'm not the cool one. But the rules are just different in our house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I get better grades than Wendy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She does. She's so smart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me just grab the candy worms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your rules are ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't sass me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm only sassing you because you're throwing out all the food in our house and I'm freaking starving. You're being stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy, can you go stand in the other room, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Wendy exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me your iPhone now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nougat things are good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have all my contacts in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, if you don't give me your phone right now, then I'm going to have to take away your phone and your computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need my computer to do homework.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No phone, no computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is B.S. This is a bunch of F- ing S. You're acting like a B.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids! Time to go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go to your room right now. Sadie runs off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling after her) You are not allowed to use iPhone, iPad, iPod Touch, iTunes, Netflix, Pandora, or Spotify! Pete enters from the hallway. He sees Larry and turns aro before anyone notices him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a little pip. Just like her mommy. So I might have a job tomorrow, at least I'm going to go try to give an estimate. Do you mind taking the kids for a couple hours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (conflicted) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is nice. You and I don't spend enough time together, do we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We spend enough time together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's quality time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we do. I'll go with what you think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete and Debbie are in bed. Pete is reading Sadie's iChat her confiscated iPad out loud to Debbie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else did they say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some kid named Joseph--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know Joseph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do? He's making a "Hot or Not" list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Sadie said, "That's so   lame and immature that you're doing   that." And then Joseph says, "Yo,   girl. We're just having some fun   so don't be a bitch, yo."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is not nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, then Sadie said, "Don't call me a bitch." And Joseph said, "I didn't call you a bitch, I said don't act like a bitch. And by the way you're in the `Not Hot' column."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who made him the judge of hot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you realize what that could do to her self-esteem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a little fuckhead. I'll kill him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So then Sadie said, "You're in the jackass column. I've got to go. I'm bored of you."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is cool. That's taking the high road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For some reason, there's an emoticon of a panda doing push-ups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder what that means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think it means anything, I think it's just adorable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aww. She's a good girl. She was polite, and she stood up for herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's pretty cool. They hear a door slam. Debbie gasps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. I thought she was coming in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god, that scared me to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she caught us, she would kill us. Debbie starts looking through the iPad. Pete's iPhone chi He sees a message from Ronnie from work. It reads: "Got t numbers. Call me." Pete looks ashen. He looks over at Debbie who is obliviou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to make a call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete paces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering loudly) We sold how many?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six hundred and twelve album downloads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. There are no zeros after that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are zeros, but all of them are before six hundred and twelve. There are none after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is that even possible?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of three hundred million Americans, six hundred and twelve people chose to download the album. You could personally call everyone who bought this record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're fucked! Here's the deal. I want you to meet me tomorrow morning at eight o'clock. I want a list of at least thirty ideas of what we can do to change this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to change this. I started a record label because I couldn't get a job, so I have no other options.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete is driving. Sadie and Charlotte sing show tunes loud and happily. Pete is very upset about the record not sell

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie is talking to their ACCOUNTANT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What financial problems?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, for one thing, you were right, you are missing about ten thousand dollars from the store. And then, Pete's record not selling well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we weren't supposed to hear for three weeks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they're bad. You know, it's that, and it's the money that he's been lending to his father, that's creating a strain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much have we lent him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eighty thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you say "eight thousand" or "eighty thousand"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eighty thousand, over the past couple of years. And then you missed the mortgage payment--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you missed the rental on the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does Pete know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. We're on the phone all the time. Look, I know you're going through a hard time, and I want you guys to know that we're here for you, okay? Anything you guys need, that's why we're here. We're here for times like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's not much I can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete enters and walks into Ronnie's office. Ronnie is dra on a blackboard behind his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm drawing the album cover for Van Halen's Diver Down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you spent a little bit more time focusing on Graham Parker instead of drawing album covers, I wouldn't be in this predicament.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm focused on Graham Parker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're supposed to help me with him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're supposed to call the companies, you're supposed to get people to the show!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've done everything I can, Pete. You had me pushing around a corpse. It was like being in fucking Weekend at Graham's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What should we do? I'm out of ideas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fly in The Rumour. I can't sell a reunion concert without the band. It's ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With what? I can't afford it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You put this on yourself. You wanted the responsibility, take it on the chin, and stop acting like a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you call me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chin. Pete walks out of Ronnie's office and into the main offic space. Ronnie follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete -- wait. I have an apartment, I have health insurance, I have car payments. I have responsibilities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't talk to me about responsibilities. I have a life. I have a family. I can't afford to sit in my apartment getting high, jerking off, and then going to Tommy's Chili Burgers at three in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not even the order that happens in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have everything to lose here. Everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Because you spent thousands of dollars on shit we don't need. You really need to spend thirty thousand dollars on a fucking neon sign, dude? Which is inside? It's not even outside. We know where we work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want to sign a band, you have to look like you're the real deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Cat) Princess Labia, how much is it to fly The Rumour in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's twelve thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve thousand dollars!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what? Fine. Fly in The Rumour. Put it on my AmEx.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie sits in Dr. Pelligrino's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you said it was impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I said it was impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I usually don't say impossible. I like to leave some wiggle room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said that my fibroid was like a giant boulder, like the one from the Indiana Jones movies blocking up my uterus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I need to stop using that reference of Indiana Jones. I think that's not appropriate when talking about the reproductive system.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, somehow the Eastern medicine has worked and the fibroid has dissipated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Your fibroid shrunk, and somehow it allowed you to get pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to have your third baby. Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Debbie does not react.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like some water?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good news. Another baby, at forty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am thrilled. And Pete is going to be so happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you're okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a relief. I can finally relax now, you know? I'm so happy, I really am. It's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie drives. We cannot tell what she is feeling. Then a a few beats, a joyous smile appears across her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete takes a framed item off of his wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry answers the door. Pete is there with a framed drawi made by John Lennon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, why are you in a bathrobe? It's the middle of the afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took a late shower. Why are you busting my balls? Look, I'm sorry about the record. You're going through financial shit. This is what I live with. This is a horrible time in human history. What is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something that might help both of our situations. Pete hands him the drawing.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is a drawing by John Lennon. I got it ten years ago for five thousand dollars. I don't know how much it's worth now. Could be five, could be twenty.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I don't want this. I don't even like it. I'm not going to hang it up.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: It's not for you to hang up. It's for you to sell. That way I can give it to you and you can make some money, and Debbie doesn't know that I'm giving you anything.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Well, you're not giving me money. You're giving me a project. I don't know how to sell this. I'm not an art dealer.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Just sell it online. Do some research, make some calls. Or is that too hard to do with your high blood pressure?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: All right. Don't get snippy. Just because you write a great song doesn't mean you can draw.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: It's incredible. John Lennon drew it.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I think it's a Ringo. Don't beat me up if I get three hundred dollars for it.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Don't take less than sixty-five hundred for that. It's very valuable. It's important to me. I want you to sell it so I can help you.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you at my party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What should I bring? You want wine or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Don't buy wine with my money and give it to me at my party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you. Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Bye... How do I call eBay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sadie and a bunch of other kids are building sets for a school play. Sadie talks with a FRIEND. Pete and Debbie are watching from afar, sitting next to e other. Debbie tries to gently break the news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's so cute. She's so tall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. How did that happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you ever wish we had a bigger family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, never for a second. Never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never. I love what we have. One? A breeze. Two? Brutal. Three? Put a bullet in my head. Debbie is totally deflated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think about that gray-haired pregnant lady from school and I just feel bad for her. And I feel bad for the kid. Can you imagine? All the other little kids, "Where's your mommy?" "Oh, she's the one sitting in that scooter eating a soft cracker." Kids don't want to have old parents. You know, it would also be nice for us to spend some time apart. Kind of rediscover who we are individually. It would be so great to not see you for like a chunk of time so that I could really just miss you. Remember when we used to miss each other?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie is walking through the campus upset. She sees a ki and darts over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! JOSEPH (13), the kid who insulted Sadie on her Facebook, turns and sees Debbie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yo, sup?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Sadie's mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sadie...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sadie, the one you chat with on the internet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah, man. That ain't me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it was you, I saw your picture. Did you make a "Hot" list and not put Sadie on the "Hot" list?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was not on my list, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I'm going to do? I'm going to make my own "Hot" list, and you know what? You're on the "Not Hot" list. How does that feel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't bother me. I'm comfortable with the way I am. She gets even quieter, scarier and more in his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you shouldn't be so comfortable with yourself. You know why? You look like a miniature Tom Petty. How's that feel? Huh? You think that haircut's cool? It's not. It looks like you put your Justin Bieber wig on backwards. You still comfortable with yourself? Why are you wearing a tank top? Huh? So you can show off your bald pits, you little hairless wonder? Cool tank top, man. So next time you think about writing something nasty on my daughter's Facebook page, just remember me. Remember me. I will come down here, and I will fuck you up. Joseph looks upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Hey. Are you crying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just let me go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I'm not in my right head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand. My mom is going through menopause, too. It's a hard time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going through menopause?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going through menopause! I'm not going to go through menopause for twenty years. I'm pregnant you little bitch. God damn it! She storms off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie pulls open the door, Pete is on the toilet playing his iPad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going out to coffee with Desi to find out if she's stealing from us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got the Graham Parker concert. Who's gonna watch the kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Figure it out. Debbie exits. Pete flips her off after she's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie and Desi are talking as they walk down the stairs a loud club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted to talk. Maybe we could go to a coffee house or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want coffee? This place has coffee. They have all kinds of drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie and Desi talk to a group of young men, PROFESSIONA HOCKEY PLAYERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What sport do you guys play?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We play hockey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I like hockey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do you guys play for?

dialogues.text: We play for the Philadelphia Flyers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys are all from Philadelphia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, actually none of us are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you guys still have all of your teeth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I've got all my teeth, except for these ones. He takes a plate of his teeth out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to try them on? Desi takes them and tries to put them in her mouth. Every laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I look sexy? Desi looks insane. She tries to kiss Debbie. Everyone is laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They definitely look way better on her than they do on you. She hands the teeth back to their owner. He pops them bac and everyone cheers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, should we go to the quiet area?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We kind of have to have a little business meeting tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Business meeting? You have to celebrate with us. We won tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to party with these winners, come on Deb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come dance with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinks about it) Okay. Let's fucking dance! Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete on stage in a half-filled nightclub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you so much for coming, this is so exciting! For the first time in over thirty years, Graham Parker and The Rumour. Pete watches Graham Parker perform with his band. The son amazing. It is about issues Pete is going through, and he really connecting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ronnie) Where are his fans? Where are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hard to watch a band when you know all of them remember D-Day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's press turnout like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you serious? Nobody came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody is here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, the guy from Green Day is here. BILLIE JOE ARMSTRONG sits nearby, watching the show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Billie Joe, I emailed him. He's a fan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Can you become a vegetarian tomorrow?

dialogues.text: No. Sadie storms in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys have been reading my texts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we haven't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, we have. We're supposed to keep an eye on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you find out?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Joseph told me that you flipped out on him and his mom and that you guys are nuts, and I agree.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Don't be disrespectful.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: You're the ones who are disrespectful. Reading my texts is like reading my diary.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: You were really sweet on your iChat. We were really proud of you.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Yeah, we were going to give you your computer and phone back.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Fuck you!

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Okay, there's the first official "Fuck you."

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: That is not how we talk to each other in this house.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: You guys talk to each other like that all the time! And to Joseph and his mom. You made Joseph cry.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Joseph has a crush on you. You like a boy who cries.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Shut up, Charlotte. You guys so desperately want me to be perfect and to make no mistakes. Well, you two are fucking insane.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All you do is fight. Or you don't fight, which is even worse because it looks like you hate each other for weeks. You obsess over every little thing I do, and you don't trust in me or believe in me. Well, I'm fucking sick of it! Yeah, I said "fuck." Fuck fuck fuck. Ground me forever I don't care. I don't care about anything. (crying hard) I hate everything, everyone's going crazy, I don't care if I have no friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you still upset about Lost?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I'm upset about Lost! You guys took away my shit before I could watch the last two episodes! I don't know what the fuck happens! She walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's becoming just like us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope I never get my period if this is what happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sadie does her homework on her bed. Charlotte brings in Sadie's electronics and puts them down in a pile beside h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you find these?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stole them. Charlotte walks away and starts to slide the door closed behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No big deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie is sitting on the couch. Pete paces around the roo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our kids are crazy. And it's our fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think there's anything we can do to turn it around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sadie's thirteen. She might be a lost cause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did she learn that kind of language? We don't talk like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no fucking idea... Do you think Sadie is this crazy because of us? Or is it hormones and Lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J.J. Abrams. He's ruining our daughter. That fucking geek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel bad for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of a sudden we're like a magnet for negativity. Why do people keep attacking us? What did we do? We're just doing our best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should we talk about our fight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we're under enough pressure. Let's just let it go this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can give each other a break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. Thank you. And I'm sorry about my dad. You're right. I'm sorry that he's just an endless mooch. (beat) The truth is, this isn't about us. It's about our parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not even mad at each other. We're mad at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just take away our parents' power by loving them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank god.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I kind of feel better already, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not us, it's them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Totally. They hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shades are closed and the room is dark. Sadie watches end of the last episode of Lost on a laptop. Pete enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing? We need to get ready for the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (devastated) I just finished the last episode of Lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't have time for this right now. We have a lot of people coming over--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (losing it) They're all dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, Kate, Sawyer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care about the show right now-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jin, Sun...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay? I need you to just get in the shower. Get dressed. Let's just put it on hold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt, Juliet. All those people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't think about Lost today. Tomorrow: Lost. All day. I can't wait to hear about it. Jack? No way. Really? Right now, shower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't make fun of your stupid Mad Men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First of all, I don't get worked up over Mad Men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's because Mad Men sucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What Don Draper has gone through beats whatever Jack is running from on some island.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bunch of people smoking in an office, it's stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're getting me off topic. Please get dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie is speaking with Barb as they set up the kitchen f barbecue for Pete's fortieth birthday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am so glad you're here. I need a buffer in case it gets weird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm ready to buff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, grab these napkins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Desi jumps in the pool in a small bikini. She is playing the water with the kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that's the girl who works for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seems nice. My wife would never let me have a hot employee like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone that works for us looks like they've been in some kind of horrible accident. Angle on Barb and Debbie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're comfortable with that around your husband?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete wouldn't know what to do with that. Angle on Barry and Pete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think our wives are looking at us right now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, definitely. Angle on Barb and Debbie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look like pedophiles. Barry and Pete turn toward their wives, smile and wave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete greets guests, including Graham and Grandma Molly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete and Ronnie are talking in the backyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Pete! Debbie walks over with Jason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason's here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, how's it going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great, you look well. How do you like what I've been doing to your girl? How do you like Debbie's after body?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, show `em. Look at this. (points to her ass) It's beautiful. Look at that after- ass. Now it starts here, but it used to start here. And I brought it up. You're welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a trainer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, well, but not just physical. Spiritual. I'm sort of a guide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys should talk. I think you'll get along. Come here, honey, I have to tell you something. They leave Ronnie and Jason alone. The guys spot Desi swimming in the pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that in the pool?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie and Pete open the front door. Standing there is Oliver. He gives a nervous smile. Debbie looks at him and tries to be nice, but we feel her effort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Debbie. She opens the door wider. They do not hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember my husband, Pete?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. I didn't recognize you with the long hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (people pleasing) I've been growing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy birthday. He hands him a bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very old scotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, wow. You know, I hope it hasn't expired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, scotch doesn't expire. It improves with age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I know. Thank you so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party is in full swing. Pete, Debbie, Oliver, Barry a Barb are getting food from the buffet. Barb and Barry are trying to help keep the conversation going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do in Chino, Oliver?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am a surgeon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow, what kind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mainly of the spine. My specialty is scoliosis surgery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mom used to talk to me like I had scoliosis because I'm a little hunchy, but that's a different thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you definitely don't look right. Larry arrives, with Claire and the triplets. Claire is holding two of them, while Larry carries one. The triplets now have very different HAIRCUTS so he can t them apart. One has a faux hawk, one has bangs, and one h buzz cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello everyone! I'm sorry we're late. I was in the lab cloning myself. We're going to have another seven more tomorrow... Look, we cut their hair different so we can finally tell who they are. Larry lifts one of the triplets up and down by the arms, simulating an elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like the new haircut, Travis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Jack, damn it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you are. Larry puts Jack down and he runs off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry, this is my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver. "Can I have some more? Please, Oliver, I need a little morsel." I love that movie. You must get that all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Claire, Larry's wife. Very good to see you, but excuse me, I'm going to go get the kids. Claire runs off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We won't see her now for the whole day. I'd help honey, but I've got the blood pressure, and I don't want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, you want a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, a little white wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White wine? Okay, heavy stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, who knew that Debbie had a dad! Where have you been for fifteen years? Never seen you at Hanukkah, Christmas, Ramadan, nothing. How do you get out of all that stuff? Do you have a wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife is at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't she come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Construction. They're sanding our deck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You let the woman sand the deck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She supervises it, yes. Sadie, Charlotte and Desi walk over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look how big the kids are. Sadie! He gives Desi a hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Larry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sadie) Hi, Sadie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom. Who is Oliver?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he your dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is my biological father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He and my mom had a baby and that was me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, so you're our grandpa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you ask your mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, well, that would make him your grandpa. Do you want him to be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Then we get another grandpa. Come on! Oliver gets up. Charlotte, Sadie and Desi run off. Oliver follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was deeply uncomfortable. Thank god the pretty girl was here to divert our attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Desi is gracefully swimming under water. She looks gorgeo She sees Jason and Ronnie under water, but they look grotesque, red-faced and awkward. They both reach for eac other and come to the surface.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hi. I did not see you there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw you there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you guys come together? Are you a couple?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we didn't come together. Absolutely not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, the mustache is a little--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just assumed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a straight man mustache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is the different between a gay man's mustache and a straight man's mustache? Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The smell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Desi swims away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry is talking to Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: So, spinal surgery just seems to me to be at the top of the surgery chain.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Well, we're not cardio, we're not neuro, but I like to think we're an important part of the spectrum.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Do you operate every single day?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Most days.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Multiple times a day?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Three, four times.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: So what's the price range? Like if I wanted--

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Oh, I'd rather not say.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: It's so big you're embarrassed to say.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I wouldn't say embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Are there hunchbacks today?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I've never seen one.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Well, that's because there are spinal surgeons.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: That's because of you. Each time I don't see a hunchback, you're getting that much richer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver smiles, amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like The Beatles, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who doesn't like The Beatles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason and Ronnie are talking to Desi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's your sun sign?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Libra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for me, that's not good. Sexually we are completely incompatible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's such a shame. That's as bad as it gets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a Cancer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does it mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's really strange. Well, Taurus and Cancers are sort of soul mates of the Zodiac. We're like perfectly compatible. I balance what you lack, and you make up for what I lack. And a quiet Cancer almost always has a huge penis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) You're making me embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie, Pete, Larry, Oliver, Barb and Barry are eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to make a toast. Thank you guys so much for coming... Pete's turning forty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we're ready to start this new phase of our lives with open hearts. Ready to just choose joy and forgive everybody, so thank you all for coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. Forgive who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think she just meant generally. You know? Put the past behind us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And live without resentments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But specifically who are you forgiving? I like to know the details before I toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you and my dad and others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. I know you have some issues with me, but I'm curious, what's he in for? Before today nobody even knew he existed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My parents divorced when I was really young and we don't spend that much time together and I'd like to work on that. Just like we'd like to work on how you have financial issues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Larry) She means all the lending. And the borrowing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what she meant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronnie, Jason, and Desi talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a beautiful woman, but you are not totally maxed out. I would say honestly, you're a six. Six and a half. I could make you an eleven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I found Deb, she was a seven. And now she's a twelve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to be a twelve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't be lazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to be lazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at me. You cannot be lazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't be lazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know how she got her body? Bodies By Jason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bodies By Jason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bodies By Jason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now just say Jason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) Jason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sounds right, doesn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck is happening right now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When was the last time you two saw each other, if you don't mind me asking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, we had lunch together last week.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: And before that?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: It's been about seven years.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Seven years? That's a joke, right? That's like two Olympics. And I'm the bad guy. What Debbie doesn't understand is that it's not bad to help out a parent. And it's certainly not bad for a parent to help out a child. I'm sure Oliver would agree.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Are you really doing this right now?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Am I doing what? I didn't start the toast.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Are you really about to hit up my dad for money?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: What? He does four operations a day. It's perfect. It helps everybody, and it relieves his guilt from all the abandonment issues.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: You can't buy forgiveness, right Pete?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I don't think anyone's looking for handouts... We'd pay him back.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: If you two are in a bind I'd be more than happy to help.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: No. It's not good to borrow money from family members because it causes resentment, remember?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do? Admit that my life is shit? Is that what you want me to say? You happy? Aren't I allowed a little joy with these children I never wanted to have?

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: You have never once stopped asking us for money.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Family helps family.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: It's true. Family helps family. Look, I don't expect you to fully understand. Your dad left. You're broken inside. It's not your fault you can't feel love. There's something that you can't -- this is coming out wrong.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: You know what? I would rather have my dad than your dad, because he doesn't drive me crazy. You know the best quality my father has? He asks for nothing. I don't know what the fuck he's thinking right now. Look at that. Nothing. I don't even know him. And I turned out perfectly fine without his input.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I just figured out what your problem is. You hate Jews. Which is so odd because your children are Jewish.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Don't play the Jew card, Larry.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I'm not playing any Jew card.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Seriously, it's used up.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: You can't use up a Jew card. That's the whole point of a Jew card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. You can't use it up, it goes forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what? I have to go. Oliver gets up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. What a big surprise. Bye Oliver. See you later. See you in another seven years. Make sure to say goodbye to the grandkids, who you met today. You know, nothing I do is right because of you? Nothing. No matter how hard I try, I'm just the asshole here, but you know what I realized? It's you. You're the asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck working that out. Happy birthday and go fuck yourself. Oliver walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you when the Cubs win the Pennant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to light the candles. Get it going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we should try the toast again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you be quiet? (to Pete) You just threw me under the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. We agreed to let go and forgive, but then you started ripping into my dad like a crazy person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not ripping into your dad. I'm just saying to him what you say to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be such a ball buster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not a ball buster. You make me one! I am a fun girl! I am fun- loving! I am a good time Sally! I dance hip-hop. I cannot believe I've wasted my whole life busting the balls of people who have no balls. I am the only one here who has any balls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham Parker sings "Happy Birthday" to Pete as Charlotte accompanies him on a keyboard. The party is tense. Debbie looks over and sees that Oliver never actually lef He stands in the back looking uncomfortable, quietly sing She's shocked he's still there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie smokes a cigarette at the side of the house. Sadie appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom? Debbie turns, caught.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom! What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're smoking? In the front yard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, they're Barb's. She walks away towards the house. Sadie follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sadie storms through the front door after Debbie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom! Since when have you been a smoker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a smoker. Debbie keeps walking down the hall. Sadie follows her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you said smokers die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't smoking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw you. Barb is in the kitchen with Pete and Charlotte.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, you're smoking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deb, you can't smoke, you're pregnant. You've been doing so well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're pregnant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No f-ing way. I don't want another sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want her as a sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I'm so sorry. It just slipped out. Debbie turns the corner to find Pete standing in front of fridge, stress eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mouth full of cupcake) Are you really pregnant? Since when are you pregnant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since when do you care? You don't want another baby.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You have no idea what I want.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: I want an Asian baby.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: We're not going to have an Asian baby.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Yes, we are!

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: They're not Asian.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Sadie.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: We'll buy one.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Shut up, Charlotte.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: You shut up!

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Shut up, Sadie!

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Shut up, Charlotte!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Okay, Sadie. Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Shut up, Charlotte!

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Okay, stop saying shut up!

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Since when are you pregnant? When did you find out?

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Will you stop eating cupcakes, please! Stop eating cupcakes. Stop eating cupcakes!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie storms off back towards the foyer. Larry pops out the living room, stopping Debbie in the foyer. Claire and triplets are right behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! We just heard. You're having a baby! See, it can happen to anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is so wonderful. We're so happy for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete throws his cupcake against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Charlotte) This is too adult for you. Let's go outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry and Claire walk away as Pete storms in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess we're stuck together forever, then, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weren't we always?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't even want a baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I do. I never said that. Look, I didn't want one if I could choose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should put that on a Hallmark card. That's beautiful. Oliver passes Pete and turns to Debbie as Pete walks away

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck with the pregnancy, Debbie. But please, take care of yourself. It's a much riskier pregnancy after forty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not forty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you are. You were born on December 5th, 1972.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was there. I'm the one who took your mother to the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what she said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mom was in labor for only twenty minutes. It was like you couldn't wait to meet me, can you imagine that? Debbie is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't even know you. You can't just come into my house and reminisce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking out) Look, maybe we were just not meant to be in each other's lives. I'm not sure this was such a great idea. Debbie follows him out the door and onto the front porch. closes the door behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, wait a minute. You did leave. And you didn't come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting agitated) My first life was ruined. I did my best with my second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I ruined your life? I was eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People do better when I stay out of their lives. That's what my son tells me. You think my life is so perfect? I've got a thirteen-year- old who's a pot head, I've got a wife who's keeping Zoloft alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never said that before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't think I want to talk to you about this? To share it with you? It's just not our way! We don't talk to each other, we don't know each other. I thought that's the way you wanted it. How do I get out of this? How do I get you all to just help me down off the cross? Debbie looks at him for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sound just like Sadie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Sadie? No. Your daughter, your younger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The big one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your older. I know that! She's a wonderful girl. Larry opens the door and peeks out. We reveal that everyo at the party (except Pete) is still standing in the foyer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, guys. Some of us need to leave. Would this be a good moment to sneak out? From the side of the house we see Pete storming by on his bike, wearing his street clothes and a helmet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Dad going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete exits his home riding his bike. He is very angry. He rides with great emotion like he is trying to get all the frustration out of his body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best birthday ever! Pete rides his bike onto San Vicente Boulevard. Pete rides down the street. A CAR passes by him. When it a fifteen-year-old TEENAGER sticks his head out the windo and yells to scare Pete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bike lane, asshole! Pete almost falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you, you Twilight pimply-ass motherfuckers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie and Barb are cleaning up. They look out the window see Oliver picking up glasses and putting them in a bin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your dad's still here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. It's weird. Where the hell is Pete? Sadie walks in with Joseph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, is it okay if Joseph hangs out here for a while?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Hi, Joseph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want a piece of cake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah sure. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sadie walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, then. Joseph follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are so cute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So cute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks exactly like Tom Petty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no bike lane and cars going very fast have to sw to avoid Pete. A car honks when traffic clogs up behind h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go around! A car makes a right turn, and Pete almost rides right int it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch it! He pulls up alongside Jason's van. Desi is riding with Ja

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Pete. Great party! They speed off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. The best!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver and the kids are playing with an iPhone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you shake it. And then a restaurant comes up. Debbie walks outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad? Excuse me. I'm going to go look for Pete. Would you mind staying with the girls for just a little bit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shocked) Well, if you want me to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't mind. You don't have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. (beat) Can I let Sadie show me the last episode of Lost? She asked me if I'd seen it, I haven't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be nice. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Debbie exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sadie) She said we could watch it. Sadie turns to Charlotte, puts her arm around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to let you watch Lost. Come on. Charlotte smiles, delighted to be accepted by her sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it scary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll cover your eyes if it gets too scary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete starts riding really fast and passes a car. When the stops for a red he keeps going, tears off to the left, crosses four lanes of traffic in both directions and almo gets hit. Pete rides his bike up a steep hill. He passes some other bikers almost hitting them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie drives around the neighborhood with Larry in the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you mad at me? Did I say something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shh. Larry, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete flies down a steep hill going crazy fast. Close up o his front wheel shaking. It is as if he wants to crash. He rides down the street when suddenly a MAN IN A RANGE R opens his door to exit his car and Pete slams directly in the man's car door -- hard, breaking the man's window and falling to the ground. The man is an incredibly thick fifty-five-year-old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you fucking kidding me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You opened your door on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't open my fucking door on you. I opened my door! Pete slowly gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was right there! You are supposed to look before you open your door. I was in the fucking bike path.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a blind spot. There's no fucking bike path. This is a residential section. Get your head out of your ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pay attention!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open your god damn eyes. What are you doing, sleepwalking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're supposed to look to see if a biker is coming through. You're supposed to look!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not my job to look out for you. You look out for yourself. I don't look out for you. I don't see you. I don't now where the fuck you are and what you're doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one is ever looking out for me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need your name and number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you're going to pay for my door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drive near the scene of Pete's accident and overhear

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you pay for my bike -- and my face, you fucking prick! The man punches Pete in the face where he's already bleed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie sees the punch and gasps, realizing it's Pete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete looks stunned. He punches the man in the gut, to no effect. The man punc Pete back in the stomach. Pete sinks to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't disrespect me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie watches Pete fall to the ground. She opens the car door and starts to run over toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure that's him? I don't think that's him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the man starts his engine, Debbie runs toward Pete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in pain) I'm going to write down your license plate number. The car drives away, revealing that it is new and has dealer's plates with no numbers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Range Rover of Sunland." Debbie reaches him and holds his head up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie and Larry sit in the waiting area of the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess the party didn't turn out like you planned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't a good party. A NURSE walks over to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. I'll bring you in as soon as his x-rays are finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he has a broken rib and he's been crying a little bit, but he'll be fine. The Nurse walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Pete was never a real fighter. But that's why he married you. That's why he loves you. Because you're the fighter, and you need that. One person in a relationship has got to punch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mean that in a good way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's a high compliment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I know what you're worried about. You think he's going to turn into me, but I don't think it's going to happen. He's smarter and probably a little cuter. A little less Jewy. Although, after fifty, that's all going to change. Be prepared to wake up one day with a a rabbi. But the good news is, he'll love you forever. That's in our DNA. We stick around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He worries about you. It puts a lot of pressure on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I just don't have anyone else to talk to about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can talk to Claire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. If I open up to her she'll leave me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, she won't, Larry, she loves you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, but there's a certain point at which you just can't stay. (beat) I guess it's hard to forgive somebody if they don't formally apologize to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you apologizing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very close. (beat) Yes, I'm sorry. And I'm glad everybody's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. She hugs him and starts to cry a little bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is awkward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need forty dollars for a cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) That's funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not kidding. You drove me. I wasn't prepared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only have a hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay. I'll bring you the change. He grabs the bill out of her purse and walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, give him a kiss for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver is sitting on the couch with Charlotte and Sadie watching the last scene of Lost. Joseph has joined them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, it's not sad, it's happy because they helped each other achieve their destiny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. I'm going to have some freaky ass nightmares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie walks into Pete's room, sits on the bed next to hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really liked our lives so much better before we tried to change everything. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: No. I'm sorry. I don't want to keep anything from you. I love you. You're my wife. I just didn't want to let you down.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Are you mad that I'm pregnant?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: No. I'm not mad. I'm thrilled.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: You don't feel trapped?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Sometimes I feel like I trapped you.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: I don't feel trapped.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You should, because I've trapped you. You can't go anywhere. I'm going to get you pregnant every ten years for the rest of your life. You can never leave me. Ever.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: I never feel trapped by you. I'm so happy to be with you. I love you so much. You're my favorite person in the whole world. god damn it, why am I crying like this? Something is wrong with me.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You're pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. Shit. I was just outside telling your dad that I liked him. What if he thinks I like him now?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: No, he won't think that.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: I don't want him to think I like him that much.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: It'll never happen.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: (suddenly giddy) Can you believe it? This is the craziest thing ever. What are we going to do with a third baby?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I have no idea. How are we going to afford it?

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: We'll sell the house.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: We don't have to.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: We kind of do.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: We kind of do.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: We'll make new memories in a new house.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Is there anything you want to do for your birthday? It's been the worst birthday ever.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: There is one thing, but I don't think you'll like it.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I wouldn't mind going to see some music. Would you want to do that?

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? I don't believe you, but you're sweet for saying that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do we break you out of here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can just leave on my own volition. It's not a mental institution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not like One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest. Please don't put a pillow over my face. Debbie laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get out of here, McMurphy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got it, Chief. Will you carry me? As Debbie helps Pete off of the hospital bed, Pete kisses passionately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete and Debbie watch Ryan Adams perform "Lucky Now" with band.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like this song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Why? Pete smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you sign him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan Adams? No, he wouldn't sign with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? You're the best. She smiles at him and he smiles back, almost blushing. Th is the smile he has been waiting for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he is in between labels. Let's go try and talk to him after the show. The camera pulls back as Ryan Adams finishes his song.
